audio.errorNoOggOpusSupportByApple: Your browser does not support OGG/Opus (taf) files at the moment. If you are using an Apple device, help us out by submitting a ticket to Apple for a fix!

toniesJson.text: You are welcome to support us by sending us the missing data of the Tonies listed below. In the future this will be possible directly in TeddyCloud, at the moment you can use TeddyBench. Thank you in advance!
toniesJson.title: Contribute tonies.json

faq.intro: Here you can find answers to some frequently asked questions. If your question is not answered here, please visit the forum or use the Telegram group to get assistance.
faq.title: FAQ

translations.hint: If you see any bad translation, please come back to us on Telegram. French and Spanish are currently completely translated by ChatGPT.
translations.title: Translations

faq.answer: To force an update, perform a freshness check on your Toniebox. Press and hold one of the ears for approximately 3 seconds until you hear a sound. Wait until a second sound confirms the completion of the update.
faq.question: How can I force an update of a Tonie after assigning new content in TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: Use the Audioencoder tool and add up to 99 audio files. Each file will be assigned its own track in the created TAF file.
faq.question: How can I create a multi-track TAF file?

faq.answer: You can add up to 16 Tonieboxes to a single TeddyCloud instance.
faq.question: How many Tonieboxes can I add to a TeddyCloud instance?

faq.answer: Place the tag on a connected Toniebox. It will automatically be added to your Tonies in TeddyCloud. If you have many unknown tags, you can filter for the last played tags or open the Toniebox management page and click on the last played tag.
faq.question: How can I add a new tag to TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: The easiest way to remove a tag is to hide it. Open the information modal for the tag you want to remove and click the 'Hide' button. The tag will remain hidden until it is placed on a Toniebox again. Alternatively, if you have access to the SD cards of all connected Tonieboxes, you can delete the tag physically by removing the corresponding content folder for that tag on each box and then removing it in TeddyCloud content view.
faq.question: How can I remove a tag from my TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: Set up a separate content directory for each Toniebox in the Toniebox management settings. Afterward, the Tonies overview will feature a dropdown menu in the top right corner where you can choose between different content directories. You don't need to assign a unique content directory to each box; boxes with the same content directory will be grouped together in the Tonies overview.
faq.question: How can I manage different contents for a tag on different Tonieboxes?

faq.answer: Perform a freshness check on that Toniebox. This will re-add all tags that have ever been placed on the box (and are not deleted) to TeddyCloud. Original Tonies need to be placed at least once to get the cloud authentication and download their linked content to TeddyCloud.
faq.question: Why is the Tonies overview empty after adding a new content directory to a box?

faq.answer: Ensure that the 'nocloud' flag is set to true and verify that no one has secretly placed another tag on the box.
faq.question: Why does my tag with custom content always start from the beginning instead of the last played position?

faq.answer: Ensure the following settings are enabled: 'Cache Content' and 'Dump rUID/auth'. We also recommend enabling 'Cache to library'.
faq.question: Why isn't the content of my tags cached to TeddyCloud?

faq.answer: Make sure you're using the correct type of tag. Only original NSP SLIX-L tags are generally compatible. You will find more information about this in the forum. If you have the CC3200 version of the Toniebox, you can enable other RFID tags as well. Check the wiki for more details. Additionally, ensure there is a certain distance between the tag and the Toniebox (at least 2-3mm) as a directly placed RFID tag won't work properly.
faq.question: Why isn't my RFID tag working?

features.description: TeddyCloud is an alternative server for your Toniebox, allowing you to host the cloud services locally. This gives you the control about which data is sent to the original manufacturer's cloud and allows you to host your own figurine audio files on e.g. your NAS or any other server.

items.01provideAudioContent: provide audio content over the air
items.05convertAudio: on-the-fly convert audio streams via ffmpeg for webradio and streams
items.06definePlaylists: define tonie audio playlists (PoC in WebFrontend)
items.08filterTags: filter custom tags to prevent deletion

items.01assignContent: assign content and other properties to each tag
items.02searchStreams: search and assign webradio streams to each tag
items.03defineMetaData: define meta data of your custom tags (PoC in WebFrontend)

features.05managePlaylists: Manage your Tonie Audio Playlist library (PoC in WebFrontend)
features.06convertAudioFile: Convert any audio file to a tonie audio file

items.01singleBoxManagement: single box management, manage all as one, group boxes for management as you like
items.02cloudAccess: disable/enable cloud access and other cloud related properties
items.03maxVolume: configure maximum volume for speaker and headphones
items.06customizeSounds: customize original box sounds (ex. jingle) over the air

items.01certificates: extract/inject certificates on a esp32 firmware dump
items.04extractCertificates: Extract certificates and store in TeddyCloud

futureFeatures.05completeCustomToniesIntegration: Completion of Custom Tonies Json WebFront Integration ("Meta data of custom tags")
futureFeatures.06moreStats: More stats about your played Tonies/Tags
futureFeatures.07securityImprovements: Security improvements like Access control (tonieboxes and user)

features.title: Features TeddyCloud

identifyVersion.boxVersion: This means your Box is a

identifyVersion.tiInstruction: To find out the specific version, you have to open your Toniebox and use the main chip of the PCB for identification.
identifyVersion.generalInstruction1: If you're unable to retrieve the MAC address, you can identify the specific version of your Toniebox by
identifyVersion.generalInstruction2: it and checking the main chip on the PCB for identification. Click on the tab for each version to get more details of them.
identifyVersion.cc3200text: This version has the text CC3200R1 on the main chip as shown in the following pictures.
identifyVersion.cc3235text: Here you will also find the version on the main chip as shown in the following pictures namely CC3235.
identifyVersion.esp32text: The PCB and main chip of the ESP32 version looks like the following pictures.
identifyVersion.proceedToFlash1: Proceed to the flashing page for the selected version:

cc3200BoxFlashing.customUrlPatchHint: Please create this patch only if the existing altUrl.305.json and altUrl.tc.fritz.box.json patches are not functioning with your current TeddyCloud setup. If they do meet your needs you can proceed by clicking 'Next'.
cc3200BoxFlashing.newBoxAvailable: Please check if the new box appears in the table below. If it is not listed, something may have gone wrong. Ensure the box is visible in your Wi-Fi, that the replacement CA has been flashed, that you are booting the correct firmware slot, that all necessary patches are set, and that the correct IP/URL for TeddyCloud is being used. If the box still does not appear, check here:
cc3200BoxFlashing.hintPatchHost: Enter the hostname of your TeddyCloud instance and then click 'Create altUrl.custom.305.patch'. The patch will automatically download afterwards.
cc3200BoxFlashing.hostnameTooLong: The hostname must not exceed 12 characters.

applyingPatchesSection.introduction: The configuration of the custom Bootloader is done within the configuration file ngCfg.json located on your Toniebox SD card in directory sd://revvox/boot (you should have already placed all hackiebox NG bootloader files on your Toniebox SD card in step 2).

technicalDetailsCollapse.collapseTitle: Technical details of the configuration file
technicalDetailsCollapse.title: Configuration
technicalDetailsCollapse.section1_part1: The configuration for the bootloader is saved within
technicalDetailsCollapse.section1_part2: . All sections or keys starting with an underscore "_" are comments and will be ignored.
technicalDetailsCollapse.section1_part3: The configuration file consists of a general section and dedicated sections for the 9 available firmware slots.
technicalDetailsCollapse.activeImgDesc: Sets the firmware slot to select at startup
technicalDetailsCollapse.waitForPressDesc: Waits for an earpress on startup with a blink sequence (blue, green, cyan, black)
technicalDetailsCollapse.waitForBootDesc: Waits for an earpress on before firmware boot with a blink sequence (blue, green, cyan, black)
technicalDetailsCollapse.waitTimeoutInSDesc: Timeout in seconds for waitForPress if no earpress (hibernation)
technicalDetailsCollapse.minBatteryLevelDesc: Poweroff voltage to protect the battery. Divide through 2785 to get voltage (Standard 3.18V)
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwFixValueDesc: Magic bytes to be placed into the OFW Image during boot (can be extracted from OFW BL data[-8:-4])
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwFixFlashDesc: Magic bytes read from the ofw bootloader on flash
technicalDetailsCollapse.serialLogDesc: Enable log to UART (TX) @921600 baud. Only works for debug build!
technicalDetailsCollapse.firmwareSectionIntro: There are nine firmware slots, named ofw1, ofw2, ofw3, cfw1, cfw2, cfw3, add1, add2 and add3.
technicalDetailsCollapse.hashFileDesc: Check hash from ng-XXX?.sha file (true) or from the last 64 byte of the firmware itself (ofw)
technicalDetailsCollapse.watchdogDesc: Keep watchdog enabled when booting firmware (if booting fails, box will restart)
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwFixDesc: Add magic bytes to the firmware image to make ofw directly boot
technicalDetailsCollapse.ofwSimBLDesc: Read image to boot from flash:/sys/mcubootinfo.bin and load the image from flash:/sys/mcuimgN.bin instead of reading from sd (like the ofw bootloader)
technicalDetailsCollapse.bootFlashImgDesc: Read firmware from file on flash
technicalDetailsCollapse.flashImgDesc: Path to the file on flash
technicalDetailsCollapse.patchesDesc: List of patches to load, see:

applyingPatchesSection.section2_part1: If you want to use your Toniebox with Teddycloud we recommend using the second firmware slot. So set in the general configuration section the element "activeImg" to "ofw2".
applyingPatchesSection.section2_part2: If you have created the "altUrl.custom.305"-patch, you should copy the patch file onto your Toniebox SD card to sd://revvox/boot/patch. After that you can add the patch in the configuration section of the second firmware slot ("ofw2"). Be aware, that only one altUrl-Patch is applied. Please remove "altUrl.tc.fritz.box" and/or "altUrl.305" if they are present in the configuration.
applyingPatchesSection.finish: If you have modified the ngCfg.json as instructed, please reassemble your Toniebox and power it on. Do a freschnessccheck, wait a moment, then click 'Show available boxes' to display the available Tonieboxes in your TeddyCloud.

esp32BoxFlashing.browserNotSupported: ESP32 Box Flashing can only be used with browsers that support the Web Serial API. Unfortunately, your current browser does not support this feature. Please use a browser that supports the Web Serial API, such as Chrome or Edge.

esp32flasher.confirmFlashDialog: Do you really want to flash your Toniebox? Please ensure a stable connection and do not interrupt the process!
esp32flasher.confirmFlashDialogHint: To ensure your Toniebox works correctly, the specified TeddyCloud instance is absolutely necessary. If your TeddyCloud is offline, your Toniebox won't be able to access new content!
esp32flasher.downloadFlashFilesHint: The firmware images are stored in your server's data directory in case you want to reflash them. In case you want to save your firmware images somewhere else, you can download them and move them to a safe place:
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesAutomaticallyHint: Click the button "Extract certificates for TeddyCloud" to automatically extract and store the certificates in TeddyCloud.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesAutomaticallyHint2: Certificates will be stored in up to two locations: first, in the base client certificate directory ../{{certDir}}/ for TeddyCloud (if no certificates are already present), and second, in the folder ../{{certDir}}/{{mac}}.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHint: You can also extract the certificates manually by following the steps below.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHintP1: You can either do that with the teddycloud executable on your computer or you may do it via the docker shell
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHintP2: Please check the filename of the extracted certs, especially the case! Change them to lowercase if they are uppercase.
esp32flasher.extractCertificatesManuallyHintP3: For your first Toniebox setup with TeddyCloud, copy the certificates into the base client certificates directory. TeddyCloud uses these certificates to authenticate with the official Tonies Cloud, allowing content to be downloaded without Toniebox interaction (e.g., when you click 'Download' on a Tonie in the GUI).
esp32flasher.extractingCertificates409ResponseForceOv: The initial attempt to store certificates failed: {{error}}. Would you like to overwrite the existing files?
esp32flasher.extractingCertificatesSuccessful: Certificates successfully extracted from "{{file}}" and stored in TeddyCloud.
esp32flasher.hintESP32FirmwareFlashed: The patching should be done. Please disconnect the Toniebox from the UART, remove the short circuit from J100 and restart the box. It should now be able to connect to TeddyCloud!
esp32flasher.hintFlashESP32: Disconnect the Powersource of your Toniebox once more. Click on "Flash ESP32", if necessary choose the COM-Port. Then connect your Toniebox to power and wait till the step is done!
esp32flasher.hintPatchFlash: To apply the selected/read flash with your TeddyCloud CA certificate and possibly make other adjustments like the TeddyCloud hostname and/or WiFi credentials, click 'Patch' after entering the information or proceed to the next step without patching.
esp32flasher.hintPatchHost: Enter the desired hostname for your TeddyCloud instance.
esp32flasher.hintPatchWifi: Optionally enter the WiFi credentials for your Toniebox.
esp32flasher.hintReadESP32ImportFlash: Now disconnect the Powersource of your Toniebox. Make sure that the UART operates in 3.3V mode. Connect your UART with your PC and Toniebox (Toniebox J103 [TxD | RxD | GND] -> UART: TxD -> RxD, RxD -> TxD, GND -> GND). Short cut the J100 pinholes. Click on "Read Flash" or "Load File", then choose the COM-Port. Then connect your Toniebox to power and wait till the step is done!
esp32flasher.hostnameTooLong: The hostname should be less than 13 characters long.
esp32flasher.noPortAvailable: No port available or user aborted
esp32flasher.patchingSuccessful: Patching successful, ready to flash {{size}} MiB.
esp32flasher.portOpenFailedInUse: Failed to open this port. Already in use?
esp32flasher.wifiCredentialsIncomplete: WiFi credentials incomplete! Please enter both SSID AND password, or leave both fields empty!

esp32BoxFlashing.hint: This section is only available when using HTTPS and a browser that supports the Web Serial API, such as Chrome or Edge. If you want to flash your ESP32 Toniebox, please click on "Proceed to HTTPS", and you will be automatically redirected to the HTTPS version. Your browser might warn that the connection is not secure. This is okay; confirm it and proceed to open the page anyway. You may need to display more details in the warning.
esp32BoxFlashing.hintWiki: If you prefer not to use a browser that supports WebSerial, you can find step-by-step guidance here:
esp32BoxFlashing.hintWiki2: Please follow then the ESP32 path:
esp32BoxFlashing.linkWikiGeneral: Patching your Toniebox for using with TeddyCloud
esp32BoxFlashing.title: ESP32 Box Flashing

tonieboxes.hintLatestFirmware: For the initial setup with TeddyCloud of your Toniebox, please ensure it has the latest firmware installed. If you're unsure whether your Toniebox is up to date, connect it to the official cloud and allow some time for the firmware update to complete.
